newsitem.title: UK: OTC gold vols pick up as underlying price drops.
newsitem.headline: OTC gold vols pick up as underlying price drops.

text.p: Gold OTC option volatilities have starting picking up from all-time lows as underlying prices tumble into new, lower territory, dealers said on Monday.
"They've firmed up and it's because we're testing one extreme of the range at the moment -- the downside," one said.
Gold at-the-money one-month volatilities were bid at 5.5 percent, up from recent lows of four percent, dealers said.
Other nearby dates were about a percentage point higher than a month ago, with three-month volatilities bid at 5.75.
"On a daily basis we're seeing good buying of gold puts, which are actually priced higher than calls. We haven't seen that for a long time," a dealer said.

He noted heavy interest at $375 in recent days as the underlying price plummeted to fresh 20-month lows. Previously one-month volatilities had been at historic lows while bullion moved in a narrow range.
Bullion fixed at the lowest since March 3, 1995 in the morning at $375.10 an ounce, down from Friday afternoon's fixing of $377.00 an ounce.

Nearby dates were attracting the most attention, dealers said. Longer-term dates were up only about half a percentage point, with six-month volatility bid at around 6.25 and one-year dates about 6.75.
"It's still cheap to buy long term insurance," he said.
The effect of this week's options expiry was difficult to predict with the underlying price still sinking to fresh lows after a big sell-off last week, dealers said.

"It's hard to know what to make of it because we're in new territory. There was a lot of exposure from $378 to $380 previously but now that we're at $375, we may just stay here," a dealer said. Volumes have also picked up since gold started losing ground, although not excessively, dealers said.
"There's not an awful lot going on, but it's better than it has been for about two months. I'd call it medium quantities," one said.
Another noted that interest remained mostly in the inter-bank sector, with customer interest only slightly stronger than last month.
